bibl.title: Military Orders for Aristides Agramonte, October 23, 1900

div1.p: Special Orders #188 directs Agramonte to Quemados, Cuba. A handwritten note by Hench states his contention that Agramonte did not do any mosquito work for Lazear or Reed until Camp Lazear was operational. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Aristides Agramonte, October 23, 1900
div1.p:
Adjutant General's
OFFICE,
NOV 7 1900
ROLLS DIVISION

ORDERS, BOOKS, BLANKS & D.C. DIV.
A. G. O.
RECD. OCT 30 1900

FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 175 A
1900

HEADQUARTERS DIVISION OF CUBA,
Havana, October 23, 1900.

1. Acting Assistant Surgeon Aristides Agramonte, U. S.
Army, is authorized to make such journeys from this city
to Quemados, Cuba, and return, as may be necessary in
order to comply with the duties enjoined by paragraph 34
Special Orders No. 122, current series, Headquarters of the
Army, the travel being necessary for the public service.

2. The leave of absence for one (1) month granted to
Acting Assistant Surgeon Luther S. Harvey, U. S. Army, in
paragraph 2, Special Orders No. 189, current series,
Department of Eastern Cuba, is hereby extended one (1)
month.

3. Leave of absence for one (1) month and ten (10)
days, with permission to go beyond the limits of the
Division, is hereby granted to Major W. S. Edgerly, 7th
Cavalry.
BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL WOOD:

p.add:
Oct 23, 1900 is probably
the date when agramonte
started to help Reed at Camp
Lazear. I contend that he
did no mosquito work for
Lazear and none for Reed
until Camp Lazear was
nearly ready to Operate. So
Oct 23 shows that
up very was when his activitis
with infecting mosquitoes (as
an immune) began.
